lessonOverview.title: Unit 8 - Lesson 1
structures: B: It’s next to/opposite the hospital.
B: It’s between the post office and the bank.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can recognise and name six places (bakery, bank, pet shop, fire station, hospital, post office) when listening and looking at visual prompts.
supportStrategies: (Vocab) Use town map visuals or SB images. Point to a place and ask: “What is it?” Students respond with “It’s a hospital.” Practice with choral repetition.
stretchStrategies: Town Map Treasure Hunt – Give pairs a mini town map with hidden “treasure spots.” One asks: “Where’s the bakery?” The other answers with prepositions: “It’s between the bank and the hospital.” They race to find all places.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can ask and answer simple questions about places using “Where’s the...?” and respond with “It’s (preposition) the...” / “It’s between the... and the...”.
supportStrategies: (Speaking) Draw a mini map on the board. Ask: “Where’s the bank?” Students answer using “It’s next to the ___” or “It’s between ___ and ___.”
stretchStrategies: Town Map Treasure Hunt – Give pairs a mini town map with hidden “treasure spots.” One asks: “Where’s the bakery?” The other answers with prepositions: “It’s between the bank and the hospital.” They race to find all places.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can use the target structure “Where’s the ___?” / “It’s ___ the ___.” / “It’s between the ___ and the ___.” to talk about places.
supportStrategies: (Grammar) Prepare sentence halves on the board (e.g., “Where’s the pet shop?” – “It’s ___ the ___.”). Students match and say the complete sentence aloud.
stretchStrategies: Town Map Treasure Hunt – Give pairs a mini town map with hidden “treasure spots.” One asks: “Where’s the bakery?” The other answers with prepositions: “It’s between the bank and the hospital.” They race to find all places.

items: Unstressed vowels do not really exist in Vietnamese, so these need extra practice. Make sure the final vowel of computer is a light schwa, not a heavy com-pu-TER. Same with the final vowel of banana. Or the second syllable of elephant. And so on.

Certain common places will not overlap in style or popular concept with their Western equivalents (fire station, post office, bakery, library), whereas others are more comparable (hair salon, shopping centre)

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
